title: ANZ offset accounts still not offsetting much
text:
In a document seen by The Australian Financial Review, ANZ made an offer as recently as July 1 to reimburse a customer $10,000 after mediation over the issue.

The loyal ANZ customer of 40 years claimed the bank’s failure to properly offset his home loan with a large deposit held with the bank placed his family into hardship and contributed to them selling their retirement dream home.

After discovering the problem in late 2018, the customer spent more than a year trying to get the bank to admit its mistake, going so far as to hire a forensic accountant to prove its error, concluding the bank made “inadequate adjustments” in its treatment of the mortgage.

ANZ says it has apologised to the customer in question.

The former head of ANZ’s Australian operations and National Australia Bank’s acting CEO, Philip Chronican, admitted the bank had a big problem with offset accounts in 2014, revealing that more than 200,000 customers would be repaid up to $70 million and promising a thorough review.

But the problem has returned again and again and by March last year ANZ’s head of home loan product, Sarah Stubbings, told the Hayne royal commission the bank expected that figure to rise to half a million customers and to about $90 million in refunds by the end of 2018.

During the hearings it emerged the problem was first raised internally in 2011. The bank’s technology team raised it again in September 2014. A processing error from the bank’s data processing plant in Bangalore was also discovered in September 2016.

During her evidence, Ms Stubbings said the bank had in fact just discovered a new cohort of customers who were not captured in the original compensation process while preparing for the year-long hearings.

“It's not so much a further issue arose,” Ms Stubbings said, “We identified that it did not pick up customers who had closed their accounts between January 2013 and January 2016."

Counsel assisting the commissioner Albert Dinelli attacked the bank for taking 10 years to refund customers who were affected by a problem that occurred in 2003.

“That’s not good enough, is it? To have an issue that’s only capable of being resolved after that period of time for customers?” Mr Dinelli said.

ANZ is due to report full year results on Thursday October 31.
description: ANZ is still in the process of finding, fixing and remediating customers for a problem it first discovered in 2011.
